utterance:
Pops, there's no use talking; we've simply got
to send you to the Point.
speaker: narrator

utterance:
I'm sure I wish you could, Colonel. Father's
tried every way he could think of, but cadetships
don't go a-begging-out here, at least. The
President has only one or two at large' ap-
pointments this year, and there were over a
thousand applications for them.
speaker: George Montrose Graham

utterance:
Well, have you tried Mr. Pierce, the Con-
gressman for this district?
speaker: Colonel Belknap

utterance:
Oh, yes, sir, tried him long ago. He was
very polite-Congressmen always are. He asked
me to go round and get all the signatures to my
application I possibly could, and kept me running
for six weeks or so. Then he gave it to Mr.
Breifogle's son.
speaker: George Montrose Graham

utterance:
Yes, I remember
hearing
speaker: Colonel Belknap

utterance: TAKE THAT ONE, THEN,'
speaker: Cadet Captain Leonard

utterance: WHO COMES THERE?
speaker: narrator

utterance: MR. ROSS, YOU ARE HEREBY PLACED IN CLOSE AR-
speaker: narrator

utterance: YOU ARE WANTED AT ONCE AT THE COURT-ROOM'
speaker: narrator

utterance: I WANT YOU TO COME AND WALK WITH ME,'
speaker: Connell

utterance:
I'LL TAKE NO MORE DEMERIT ON OTHER MEN'S
ACCOUNT
speaker: narrator

utterance: WON'T YOU SHAKE HANDS?
speaker: narrator

utterance:
Mac, this young gentleman is Dr. Graham's
son George, our candidate for West Point. He
knows plainscraft, woodcraft, and mountain scout-
ing as well as you do mathematics. He can ride
as well as any man in my troop. Give him a
lift in algebra and 'math.,' and he'll teach you
all there is worth knowing about this part of
the country.
speaker: narrator

utterance:
Neither of those young
fellows, said he to Dr. Graham, "can pass the
preliminary examination. It is by long odds
too stiff for Breifogle mentally and for Murphy
physically. Keep this to ourselves, and get Mr.
Pierce to promise that George shall have the
next vacancy.
If we can get the Colonel to ask
it, Pierce will say yes, perhaps; first because they
served together in Virginia during the war, and
second because he won't think he's promising
anything at all. It's his first term, and he doesn't
dream how hard that examination is, or how cer-
tain Breifogle is to fail. Now, if there were only
some way we could 'get a pull' on him.
speaker: Ralph McCrea

utterance: That 'll make him act,
speaker: Brent

utterance: Rush this out to the fort!
speaker: Brent

utterance:
First National just robbed by Hatton gang.
Ten men. Ninety thousand gone. Government
funds mostly.
speaker: Brent

utterance:
They're making for Marcy's Pass.
You can head 'em off by Squaw Cañon if you
send cavalry at once. We follow trail. Answer.
speaker: Brent

utterance: Mount your troop instantly, Lane!
speaker: Colonel Belknap

utterance:
Never
mind their supper; they can have that later.
Listen to this.
speaker: Colonel Belknap

utterance:
Turn out, 'E' troop, lively; carbines and re-
volvers, fur coats and gloves. Jump now, men!
speaker: narrator

utterance:
Who can lead them? What scouts have you
on your roll who know the hills?
speaker: Colonel Belknap

utterance:
No scouts left, sir, now; but we don't need
them. Here's Geordie Graham.
speaker: Ralph McCrea

utterance:
We never could have got them in all the
world, sir, but
for Pops here. He knew the way, even in the
dark, and we headed them off in the nick of
time.
speaker: Captain Lane

utterance:
It is ten years since I went up for my exam-
ination, just as you are to go, Pops-an army
boy who had had precious little schooling; but
I don't remember any problems as hard as this
one.
speaker: Ralph McCrea

utterance:
It seems a queer confession, but I don't believe I could begin to pass the en-
trance examination to the Academy, from which
I was graduated so many years ago. I certainly
couldn't without months of preparation.
speaker: Captain Lane

utterance:
There are only three months left for prepa-
ration, said Graham; "the question is how to
employ the time to best advantage. George is
willing to study hard, and you and I to teach,
but what I'm thinking is that we may be wast-
ing time on immaterial points and neglecting
some that are essential. Would it not be best to
send him on and have him study under some one
who knows just exactly what is needed?
speaker: George Montrose Graham

utterance: Yes,
speaker: Ralph McCrea

utterance: try to have you leave the fort, Geordie, but what's more, sir, there isn't a man but that's glad he's going to West Point, and that wouldn't like to see him with us again as our Lieutenant.
speaker: Sergeant Nolan

utterance: But I'm not in yet, Sergeant. There is Mr. Breifogle to be considered. If he passes, there'll be no room for me; and if he fails, why, I may too. In that event, I'll have to come back and 'list just as soon as I'm eighteen.
speaker: George Montrose Graham

utterance: Breifogle is like a great many of our people who have become suddenly rich. He thinks money and a political pull will do anything. He refuses to believe that West Point is governed by rules that even the President cannot violate. He is confident that all that is necessary is for him to go on with Fritz in June, and the examiners will not dare reject him, especially if Congressman Pierce is there, too.
speaker: narrator

utterance: I'm really sorry for the old fellow, he's so thoroughly earnest and honest in his convictions. It isn't his fault, either. It is part of the stock in trade of many politicians to make their constituents believe that for the benefit of their special friends they have it in their power to set aside laws, rules, or regulations. I haven't a doubt that Pierce has made the old man believe he 'stands' in with the Secretary of War and the Superintendent of the Academy, and that Fritz will go through West Point with flying colors. It will cost Breifogle nearly a thousand dollars to find out his mistake.
speaker: Ralph McCrea

utterance: No, Geordie, my boy, I don't like to take comfort in another man's misfortunes, but there is no chance whatever for young Breifogle and every chance for you. All you have to do is study and you'll win. I have said as much to the old man, for he stopped me at the bank the other day and asked what I thought of the case, and I told him frankly. For a moment he looked downcast; then he brightened up all of a sudden, laid his finger alongside his nose, and winked at me profoundly. Vell, you yust vait a leetle,' he said, and turned away. I've no doubt he thinks I'm only trying to bluff him out in your interest.
speaker: Ralph McCrea

utterance: Vell, you yust vait a leetle,
speaker: Mr. Breifogle

utterance: Didn't they want to get on?
speaker: George Montrose Graham

utterance: Oh yes, sir, wanted to bad 'nough; but, Lord bless you, dis train don't stop for them: they has to wait for the locals. We runs a hundred trains a day along here. Dis train don't even stop where you gets off, sir; that's why you have to change at Poughkeepsie, the only place we stop between Albany and New York.
speaker: the Pullman porter

utterance: This for Garrisons?
speaker: George Montrose Graham
addressee: a bearded official in blue and brass buttons

utterance: Where do you go?
speaker: the driver

utterance: Send my trunk up to the hotel. I'm going to walk.
speaker: George Montrose Graham

utterance: The battalion will be coming in from parade as you reach the Point, Geordie, if your train's on time.
speaker: Ralph McCrea

utterance: There's no question as to your physique, Mr. Graham. I fancy it won't take long to make you more at home in mathematics. To-morrow we'll move you into your temporary quarters down at the Falls, and next day begin studies. There are several candidates on the ground already.
speaker: narrator

utterance: No matter what you do know of actual service, Pops -and you have had more experience of army life than ninety-nine per cent. of the corps-it is best not to 'let on' that you know anything until you are an old cadet, even among your classmates.
speaker: Ralph McCrea

utterance: Those who are most volubly confident to-day, are the ones who will be most apt to fail. Keep your own counsel, 'give every man thine ear and few thy voice'-and that's all.
speaker: Ralph McCrea

utterance: No; there is just one way to win the respect and good-will of the corps of cadets, he declared, and all the letters and all the fathers and uncles and even pretty sisters combined can't win it any other way. The boy must earn it himself, and it isn't to be earned in a month, either. Every tub stands on its own bottom there, doctor. The higher a fellow's connections, the more he has to be taken down. Leastwise, it was so in my time, and West Point is deteriorating if it is any different now.
speaker: Ralph McCrea

utterance: I belonged to the high-school cadets for two years, and everybody that ever saw us drill said we could lay over anything in the whole country, and now here's this measly little stuck-up prig, that probably never knew anything about drill until he entered here last year, correcting and finding fault with everything I do. I ain't going to stand it, by thunder! I've written to my father to come on again, and just have this thing attended to right off. It seems to me if I were in your place I wouldn't stand being abused either, Graham. I heard Mr. Flint snapping at you again this morning.
speaker: Benjamin Franklin Frazier

utterance: Wa-e-1, Flint was all right, I guess. Your squad was just in front of us, and when I saw Connell stumble over your heels and try to climb up your back, I laughed out loud. He caught me chuckling.
speaker: George Montrose Graham

utterance: Yes, and abused you like a pick-pocket, by jingo! If my father were an officer in the regular army, as yours is, it wouldn't happen twice to me.
speaker: Benjamin Franklin Frazier

utterance: No, nor to me either. I'll bet you he'd sing a mighty different tune if he knew you were the son of a Major.
speaker: Connell

utterance: Well, there's just where you're 'way off. Of all places in creation this is the one where one's dad cuts no figure whatever. I've often heard old officers say that the boys who got plagued and tormented most in their time were the fellows whose fathers were generals or cabinet ministers. Fred Grant wouldn't have had half as hard a time if his father hadn't been President. Frazier's whole trouble comes from letting on that he knew all about drill before he got here; that's the truth of it. I get along smoothly by pretending never to have known anything.
speaker: George Montrose Graham

utterance: Oh, a lot you have! If that snob Loring ever speaks to me as he spoke to you this morning about laughing in the ranks, I'll—I'll just let him have my fist between the eyes, and he'll see more stars than he ever saw before, if he is a color corporal. What 'll your father say when he hears that he threatened to put you in a cell just for laughing when that Pike County fellow knocked his hat off trying to salute?
speaker: Benjamin Franklin Frazier

utterance: Well, he didn't say cell, in the first place, and father wouldn't hear it from me, at least, if he had. It's an understood thing at home that they're to ask no questions, and I'm to tell no tales until plebe camp is over and done with. Plebes don't begin to have the hard times now that they had thirty years ago, and if they could stand it then, I can now. All you've got to do is simply make up your mind to grin and bear it; do just as you're told, and say nothing about it. If this thing worries you now, when only our drill-masters and instructors get at us, what are you going to do, Frazier, when you're marched over there into camp next week and turned over to the tender mercies of the whole corps ?
speaker: George Montrose Graham

utterance: I'm going to fight the first man that offers me an indignity of any kind, by thunder!
speaker: Benjamin Franklin Frazier

utterance: What is the meaning of all this noise? Who was laughing as I came in?
speaker: Mr. Loring

utterance: I was, sir.
speaker: George Montrose Graham

utterance: You again, Mr. Graham? This is the third time since reveille I've had to reprimand you for chuckling like a school-boy-twice in ranks, and now again at inspection. What were you laughing at this time, sir?
speaker: Mr. Loring

utterance: At something Frazier said, sir.
speaker: George Montrose Graham

utterance: Mr. Frazier, sir. Never omit the handle to a gentleman's name on duty or in official intercourse. Only among yourselves and off duty can you indulge in familiarity; never, sir, in conversation with superior officers. And you are room orderly, too, Mr. Graham, and responsible for the appearance of things. Where should the broom be, sir?
speaker: Mr. Loring

utterance: Behind the door, sir.
speaker: George Montrose Graham

utterance: Then where is it, sir?
speaker: Mr. Loring

utterance: I didn't notice it until just now, sir.
speaker: George Montrose Graham

utterance: Exactly, Mr. Graham; if you had been attending to your duty instead of giggling over Mr. Frazier's witticisms you would have escaped punishment. Report at my office immediately after supper this evening, sir.
speaker: Mr. Loring

utterance: Remember that the first thing that will be sorely tested is your sense of subordination-your readiness to obey without question. No soldier is considered fit to command others until he can command himself. They purposely put a fellow through all manner of predicament just to test his grit. Don't let anything ruffle your temper, and they will soon find you need no lessons.
speaker: Ralph McCrea

utterance: Why are you on punishment to-night, sir?
speaker: Mr. Merrick

utterance: Laughing in ranks, broom out of place, and some other things, sir.
speaker: George Montrose Graham

utterance: Yes, I remember. Go to your quarters now, and keep your face straight on duty hereafter.
speaker: Mr. Merrick

utterance: One moment, Mr. Graham. Whose squad are you in?
speaker: Mr. Merrick

utterance: Mr. Flint's, sir.
speaker: George Montrose Graham

utterance: Did he teach you that salute ?
speaker: Mr. Merrick

utterance: No, sir.
speaker: George Montrose Graham

utterance: Where did you learn it?
speaker: Mr. Merrick

utterance: Among the soldiers, sir, in the garrison.
speaker: George Montrose Graham

utterance: Ah, yes, I've heard of your case. That'll do, sir.
speaker: Mr. Merrick

utterance: We'll just aggravate them by coming so near, and yet keeping aloof.
speaker: Benjamin Franklin Frazier

utterance: Is this possible?
speaker: unspecified

utterance: Who and what are you who have dared to insult the sacred office of the sentinel, the soldier to whose lightest word even the commander-in-chief must show respect? Who and what are you?
speaker: unspecified

utterance: We didn't mean any harm. We're only new cadets.
speaker: Benjamin Franklin Frazier

utterance: What!
speaker: unspecified

utterance: Are you mad? Mad!
speaker: unspecified

utterance: Is it credible that you, chosen by the deluded Representatives of your States to represent a proud community in an honorable profession-you dared to signal-ize your admission here by one of the most flagrant offences known to military law? Send at once for the Superintendent, Officer of the Guard. This is beyond my powers. Into the guard-tent with them! Batten down the walls. Station sentries at each side, Mr. Green. Put two of your most reliable men at the door, with orders to shoot them dead if they stir a muscle. Order-ly, go at once for the commandant, and warn the officers that mutiny has broken out among the new cadets.
speaker: unspecified

utterance: All I'm afraid of is that now I won't get in the first squad to have muskets. We were going to have 'em in the morning.
speaker: Benjamin Franklin Frazier

utterance: He'd show those cadet fellows a thing or two they never dreamed of
speaker: unspecified

utterance: He would need no drilling at all at West Point
speaker: unspecified

utterance: New cadets, turn out promptly!
speaker: unspecified

utterance: Mr. Graham and I would like to tent together, sir.
speaker: Benjamin Franklin Frazier

utterance: Which is Mr. Graham ? Call him here.
speaker: Lieutenant Allen

utterance: I am told you wish to tent with Mr. Frazier. Is that the case?
speaker: Lieutenant Allen

utterance: If you think of any one else you would rather tent with, I presume that it can be arranged.
speaker: Lieutenant Allen

utterance: No, sir. I had thought of no one else. I promised Mr. Frazier.
speaker: George Montrose Graham

utterance: Very well, sir. Mr. Leonard, put this young gentleman and Mr. Frazier in the same tent-two more with them. Have you any choice, Mr. Graham ?
speaker: Lieutenant Allen

utterance: No, sir.
speaker: George Montrose Graham

utterance: Connell and Foster, sir, would like to tent with us.
speaker: Benjamin Franklin Frazier

utterance: Take that one, then.
speaker: Cadet Captain Leonard

utterance: Come on, boys.
speaker: Benjamin Franklin Frazier

utterance: Mr. Frazier, the first lesson you have to learn is that very new cadets should only be seen, not heard; and when you are heard, sir, don't again allude to members of the corps of cadets of the United States Army as boys. You are here to be men, if it's in you. If it isn't, you're apt to get out of it, sir.
speaker: Cadet Captain Leonard

utterance: That's another young snob, that fellow Leonard! I'll pay him off for that yet, see if I don't.
speaker: Benjamin Franklin Frazier

utterance: TAKE THAT ONE, THEN,'

utterance: Mr. Frazier, you represent the Sixth Congressional District of the Pilgrim State, I understand.

utterance: I do, sir.

utterance:
Then it can be no one but yourself to whom this article refers. Gentlemen, fall back! Hold a candle here, somebody. Mr. Frazier, we will now permit you to give an exhibition of your ability to read aloud in the open air so as to be distinctly understood by your troops.
Your
services as adjutant - general may be needed at
any moment. Read this carefully, now.

—
have the goodness to read that just once more?

utterance: Astonishing!
speaker: unspecified

utterance: Prodigious!

utterance:
I knew there was extraordinary power in that
face the first time I set eyes on it!
speaker: unspecified

utterance:
Merciful
heavens! to think that we were on the point of

rons on his sleeves called Mr. Graham's attention

speaker: unspecified

utterance:
Now go to your tents; make down your bed-
ding just as you were taught in barracks; do not
remove your shirts or drawers or socks; hang
up your uniforms where each man can get his
own in an instant; put your shoes and caps
where you can get them in the dark, if need be;
turn in and blow your candle out before the drum
strikes 'taps,' at ten. After that, not a sound!
Get to sleep as soon as you can, and be ready to
form here at reveille.
speaker: Mr. Loring

utterance: Break ranks. March!
speaker: Mr. Loring

utterance:
Oh, I'll get square with that gang! Just
wait until I'm on guard some night next week

utterance:
You caught it nicely
for laughing, Connell. Next time perhaps you

Just wait until I get on guard, then I'll show

Mr. Graham, get ready to march on guard

utterance: Very well indeed, Mr. Graham

Where did you learn to clean a rifle like this,

speaker: George Montrose Graham

Very neat and soldierly, especially here on

That's Mr. Graham, Ralph McCrea's protégé.

poral Pops.

utterance: Very well indeed, sir!

utterance: Very well indeed, sir!

utterance: Ah! the cavalry corporal of Camp Coyote!

utterance:
Corporal, suppose that you found your
post suddenly invaded at night, sir, by the simul-
taneous appearance of the general-in-chief and
staff on the east, the commandant and corporal
of the guard on the west, the superintendent and
a brass-band on the north, Moses and the ten
commandments on the south, and the ghost of
Horace Greeley on the other side, which would
you first advance with the countersign?
speaker: Mr. Riggs

utterance:
Nice blunder you made this morning, Gra-
ham, turning your back on the officer of the
day, instead of facing him and saluting!
speaker: Benjamin Franklin Frazier

utterance: Is that so?
speaker: George Montrose Graham

utterance: When was it?
speaker: George Montrose Graham

utterance:
Oh, you needn't pretend you didn't see him!
I saw you; so did Green here. Didn't I, Green?
I spoke of it at the time. You looked right at
him as he came around from A Company street
past the adjutant's tent, and instead of stop-
ping and presenting arms you deliberately turned
your back on him, and stood facing Fort Clinton
while he passed along behind you.
speaker: Benjamin Franklin Frazier

utterance:
I was taught this morning that when an offi-
cer passed along in rear of the post without at-
tempting to cross it, simply to stand at a carry,
facing outwards. I never heard of its being done
any other way.
speaker: George Montrose Graham

utterance: Ho, ho!
speaker: Benjamin Franklin Frazier

utterance:
Why, the very
first thing a soldier's taught is to look towards
the officer he salutes, and never to turn his back.
Ain't it so, Mr. Cross?
speaker: Benjamin Franklin Frazier

utterance: You have a heap to learn yet, young man.
speaker: Mr. Cross

utterance:
A sentry always faces
outward in camp when an officer passes by, even
if he passes behind his post, in which case he
doesn't even salute. I gave Mr. Graham those
orders myself, sir.
speaker: Mr. Cross

utterance:
Now, suppose I was to come, sir, in the dead
of night to your sentry post, and demand, as your
superior officer, that you give me up your gun,
what would you do?
speaker: Mr. Woods

utterance:
Do you mean without the countersign? With-
out being an officer of the guard?
speaker: George Montrose Graham

utterance:
Exactly, sir. Simply as your superior officer
-as an old cadet to a plebe, sir.
speaker: Mr. Woods

utterance:
I'd let you have it, butt foremost, between
the eyes.
speaker: George Montrose Graham

utterance: Not here, not now, Jimmy.
speaker: unspecified

utterance: We'll 'tend to that plebe later.
speaker: unspecified

utterance:
Nothing can be done till he marches off guard
to-morrow, Woods.
speaker: unspecified

utterance:
That 'll be
time enough to settle it.
speaker: unspecified

utterance: What is your name, sir?
speaker: Mr. Glenn

utterance: Graham.
speaker: George Montrose Graham

utterance: Toss up your rifle.
speaker: Mr. Glenn

utterance: Did you clean this gun yourself, sir?
speaker: Mr. Glenn

utterance: Yes, sir.
speaker: George Montrose Graham

utterance:
If this were not your first tour of guard
duty, Mr. Graham, and you had not to learn sen-
try duty, I would put you on colors.
speaker: Mr. Glenn

utterance: Keep your eye peeled, Graham.
speaker: Connell

utterance:
Some of those
yearlings are going to try and get square with
you to-night.
speaker: Connell

utterance:
I have a message for you from Mr. Woods,
Mr. Graham, and will see you after you march off guard.
speaker: Jennings

utterance: WHO COMES THERE?'
speaker: George Montrose Graham

utterance:
One might as well search for a needle in a
hay-stack, as you probably knew when you sent
him there, Mr. Bland.
speaker: Lieutenant Allen

utterance:
Go to the first sergeant of Company B
and tell him to credit Mr. Graham with a full
tour of guard duty, and order the supernumerary
to report at once at the guard-house. Mr. Jay
speaker: Lieutenant Allen

utterance:
you re-
main here in charge of this post until relieved.
Now go to your tent, Mr. Graham, and get to
bed. You've done very well, sir. This matter
will be investigated in the morning.
speaker: Lieutenant Allen

utterance:
I'll go if you order me to,
sir, but I'd rather borrow a gun and serve my
tour out, and let them try it again.
speaker: George Montrose Graham

utterance:
Very
well; do so if you choose.
speaker: Lieutenant Allen

utterance:
Did you recognize no one-did you hear no
voice-see nothing by which you could identify
any one?
speaker: Lieutenant Allen

utterance:
No, sir; it was all done quick as a flash. I
didn't hear a thing.
speaker: George Montrose Graham

utterance:
Have you had any difficulty with any
body? Had you any inkling that this was to
happen?
speaker: Lieutenant Allen

utterance: I'm waiting for your answer, Mr. Graham.
speaker: Lieutenant Allen

utterance:
Well, sir, I suppose every new cadet has
difficulty with the old ones. This was nothing
that I care to speak about.
speaker: George Montrose Graham

utterance:
With whom had you any trouble, sir? Who
threatened you in any way?
speaker: Lieutenant Allen

utterance: I decline to say.
speaker: George Montrose Graham

utterance:
You may have to say, Mr. Graham, should
a court of inquiry be ordered.
speaker: Lieutenant Allen

utterance: Very well. You can post Mr. Graham again.
speaker: Lieutenant Allen

utterance:
and you will be held respon-
sible, Mr. Officer of the Guard, in the event of
further annoyance to him to-night.
speaker: Lieutenant Allen

utterance:
There must be no repetition of last night's
performance on your guard, sir.
speaker: Colonel Belknap

utterance:
You are sure you recognized none of your
assailants last night?
speaker: Colonel Belknap

utterance: Perfectly sure, sir. I had no opportunity.
speaker: George Montrose Graham

utterance:
Have you heard anything as yet of your
rifle and equipments?
speaker: Colonel Belknap

utterance: No, sir; nothing at all.
speaker: George Montrose Graham

utterance:
Mr. Bend, issue Mr.
Graham a brand-new rifle-one that has never
been used; also new equipments. His were
taken because they were the best cleaned in the
class. We'll save him as much trouble as possi-
ble in the future—until those are found.
speaker: Colonel Belknap

utterance:
"The colonel tried to get him to tell," said he,
 in answer to eager questions, "but he wouldn't.
You're safe enough, Woods, if you don't push
matters any further."
speaker: Mr. Bend

utterance:
"But I've got to," said Woods, in a low tone.
"Jennings has seen him already, and Ross says
it's got to be one thing or the other."
speaker: Mr. Woods

utterance:
"One moment, Jennings," said Bend, joining
the two; "before you go any further in this mat-
ter, I want you to know that when many a plebe
might have been excused for giving the whole
thing dead away to the commandant this morn-
ing, Mr. Graham stood up like a man and wouldn't
tell."
speaker: Mr. Bend

utterance:
"Of course he wouldn't!" answered Jennings,
shortly. "Mr. Graham's a gentleman. All the
more reason why Woods can't swallow his lan-
guage."
speaker: Jennings

utterance:
"Well, see here; I think Woods brought the
whole thing on himself," said Bend, sturdily.
"This is no personal row, and that young fellow
has been taught all his life that a sentinel is en-
titled to respect, in the first place, and is expected
to do his whole duty, in the second. I'm not
'going back on a class-mate,' as you seem to
think, but I want you, and I want Woods here, 
to put yourselves in that plebe's place a mo-
ment, and say whether you'd have answered
differently."
speaker: Mr. Bend

utterance:
"We can't back out now," answered Woods,
gruffly. "The whole corps knows just what he
said, and it will be totally misjudged if we don't
demand apology. He's got to apologize," he
went on, hotly, "or else fight; and it's not your
place to be interfering, Bend, and you know it."
speaker: Mr. Woods

utterance:
"I wouldn't interfere if it were a simple mat-
ter of a personal row between the two; but this
is a matter in which-and I say it plainly, Jen-
nings-this young fellow is being set upon simply
because he's been raised as a soldier, and knows
more what's expected of a soldier than any man
in his class, and-by Jupiter! since you will have
it-than a good many of ours, you and Woods
in particular." And now the cadet corporal's
eyes were flashing. "What's more, Jennings, I
believe Woods's better judgment would prompt
him to see this thing as I do, but that you're
forcing a fight."
speaker: Mr. Bend

utterance:
"Not another word, Bend! Be quiet, Jen-
nings! You two can settle this later. I'm wit-
ness to what has been said; so are a dozen more.
Go about your other affair, Jennings."
speaker: Mr. Ross

utterance:
"You'll hear from me later on this score,
Bend," he growled. "I'm at Woods's service
for the moment, and I decline any officious med-
dling on your part."
speaker: Jennings

utterance:
"Here comes Mr. Jennings, Graham," said
Benny, excitedly, and the next instant the burly
figure of the A Company corporal-Woods's
friend-appeared at the tent door.
speaker: Benjamin Franklin Frazier

utterance:
"Mr. Graham, my friend Mr. Woods consid-
ers himself insulted by your language at the din-
ner-table yesterday, and he demands an apology."
speaker: Jennings

utterance: "I've none to make,"
speaker: George Montrose Graham

utterance:
"Then I suppose you will refer me to some
friend at once. You know the consequences, I
presume," said Jennings, magnificently.
speaker: Jennings

utterance:
"Just as soon as I can find some one," an-
swered Geordie. "I'll look around after dinner."
speaker: George Montrose Graham

utterance:
"Well, you want to step out about it," was
the curt reply. "There's been too much shilly-
shally about this matter already."
speaker: Jennings

utterance:
"That's no fault of mine!" answered Pops,
firing up at the instant. "Connell, you'll stand
by me, won't you? Mr. Jennings, you can have
all the satisfaction you want; and, what's more,
just you say that if I can find out who stole my
gun last night there'll be no time fooled away
asking for any apologies."
speaker: George Montrose Graham

utterance:
"Bully!" gasped Benny, with eager delight;
and Foster smote his thigh with ecstasy.
speaker: Benjamin Franklin Frazier

utterance:
"All right, my young fighting-cock!" sneered
Jennings. "We'll accommodate you-and begin
to-night during supper. See that you and Mr.
Connell here are ready."
speaker: Jennings

utterance:
"Oh, one moment, Mr. Jennings," interposed
the First Class neighbor. "Mr. Graham is pos-
sibly ignorant of the fact that as a challenged
party it's his right and not yours to name the
time. Fair play, if you please, now; fair play."
speaker: First Class neighbor

utterance:
"Oh, he'll get fair play enough," said Jen-
nings, impatiently.
speaker: Jennings

utterance:
"I may be wrong, Mr. Otis, but it's all the fault of
my bringing up."
speaker: George Montrose Graham

utterance:
"Confound the pig-headed young sawney!" said
Otis, afterwards. "He's as obstinate as a mule,
and, what makes it worse, he's perfectly right;
only the yearlings can't see it, and he'll have no
end of fight and trouble, especially if he licks
Woods to-night."
speaker: Mr. Otis

utterance:
"Take 'em a year from now," said Mr. Ross,
"and there's no question but that Woods 'll be
outclassed; but to-day it makes one think of Fitz-
James and Roderick Dhu."
speaker: Mr. Ross

utterance:
"It'll be a beauty," was the way he expressed
himself. "That plebe's a plucky one.
I may
have to give him a lesson myself yet."
speaker: Jennings

utterance:
"If it's two years from now when he tries it
on," remarked Mr. Otis, when Jennings's remarks
were repeated to him, "may I be there to see!
It's my belief Mr. Jennings will get a lesson he
richly deserves."
speaker: Mr. Otis

utterance:
"Now's your time, lad, and I've only one piece
of advice-clinch and throw him as quick as you
can."
speaker: Mr. Otis

utterance:
"Show
your foot there! No spikes allowed."
speaker: Jennings

utterance:
"It seems to me that your man has no business
wearing tennis-shoes," said Connell. "Rubber
soles give him an advantage on this turf. I pro-
test!"
speaker: Connell

utterance:
"Of course it's unfair, Ross. What's more, the
plebe's shoes are new and stiff, and the soles are
slippery. This thing can't go on until that's set-
tled."
speaker: Mr. Glenn

utterance: "Are you ready?" asked Ross.
speaker: Mr. Ross
addressee: George Montrose Graham and Mr. Woods

utterance:
"Fall back,
Mr. Jennings."
speaker: Mr. Ross

utterance:
"Watch that right, Graham," muttered Con-
nell, as he backed away;
speaker: Connell

utterance: " Go!"
speaker: Mr. Ross
addressee: George Montrose Graham and Mr. Woods

utterance: "Isn't he a young mountain-lion?"
speaker: Mr. Glenn

utterance:
"He'll be worse than a grizzly if he gets Woods
in a hug," was the reply. "Look! he's grap-
pled!"
speaker: narrator

utterance: "Run for your life, plebe!"
speaker: narrator

utterance: "WHO whipped? How did it end?"
speaker: swarm of old cadets

utterance:
"It didn't end," was the gloomy answer. "Al-
len jumped the fight and nabbed the plebe. He
recognized me, too, I reckon, though the rest of
us got away."
speaker: Mr. Ross

utterance:
"We had Woods licked," said Connell, em-
phatically. "Graham had him down when the
rush came. Everybody seemed to know which
way to go except ourselves. We ran slap into
Lieutenant Allen, and he had to stop and take
my name instead of gobbling the others. Yes;
we've got to go to the guard - tent, they say.
There's no helping that."
speaker: Connell

utterance:
"Not scot-free, either," said one lucky plebe,
who had seen the battle and yet escaped capture-
"not scot-free, by a long chalk. Mr. Woods got
one Scotch lick he won't forget in a week."
speaker: one lucky plebe

utterance: "How is it, plebe-any damages?"
speaker: Mr. Glenn

utterance:
"Hit pretty often, I
guess, but I didn't notice it much at the time.
What troubles me is that it's got Mr. Connell
into the guard-house."
speaker: George Montrose Graham

utterance:
"Well, that's just what I've come to see you
about," said Glenn. "Don't worry a particle.
No one's more sorry you were caught than Mr.
Allen himself, I'll bet. You've got to go to the
guard-tent, but that's only for a few days.
There's no dodging regulations, of course; but
there you'll be let alone, and there'll be nobody
to bother you. You've won the sympathy of
the whole corps, and you did well, plebe." And
here the adjutant put his hand on Geordie's
shoulder. "That throw was tip-top!"
speaker: Mr. Glenn

utterance:
"Mr. Ross, you are hereby placed in close ar-
rest, and confined to your tent. Charge-pro-
moting a fight. By order of Lieutenant-Colonel
Hazzard,"
speaker: Mr. Glenn

utterance:
"By thunder! that's the first time I ever
heard of colors being given to a plebe when
there were old cadets in line."
speaker: Jennings

utterance:
"Keep clear of that brute Jennings all you
can to-day," whispered Connell to his tent-mate.
"He means mischief."
speaker: Connell

utterance: All right.
speaker: Pops

utterance: Why, Graham, what's happened to your gun?
speaker: Foster

utterance: Mr. Bend, look, sir, they've taken away my new rifle and left this, my old one, in its place!
speaker: George Montrose Graham

utterance: Who has done it?
speaker: Mr. Bend

utterance:
Have you any
idea? Any suspicion ?
speaker: Mr. Bend

utterance:
No, sir, I can't accuse any one. It's too
mean a trick.
speaker: George Montrose Graham

utterance: Oh, Leonard, look at this!
speaker: Mr. Bend

utterance:
That gun has been lying in damp grass ever
since the night you lost it.
speaker: Cadet Captain Leonard

utterance:
The man who took your new one knew where
to find this, and was one of the party that downed
you. Have you still no suspicion?
speaker: Cadet Captain Leonard

utterance:
No, sir, I sup-
pose they did it out of revenge for my taking
colors this morning.
speaker: George Montrose Graham

utterance: Glenn! oh, Glenn !
speaker: Cadet Captain Leonard

utterance: Hello!
speaker: Mr. Glenn

utterance: Come here, will you? lively--I want you.
speaker: Cadet Captain Leonard

utterance: Look at that!
speaker: Cadet Captain Leonard

utterance: Hello, where did you find it, plebe?
speaker: Mr. Glenn

utterance:
In my gun-rack, sir, just now, in place of the
new one you saw at guard-mounting this morn-
ing.
speaker: George Montrose Graham

utterance: Do you mean that's gone?
speaker: Mr. Glenn

utterance: Yes, sir.
speaker: George Montrose Graham

utterance:
That'll do, then. Join your company. Leon-
ard, the man
that did this dirty trick shall be kicked out of
the corps inside of six months, if I have to drop
everything else to find him.
speaker: Mr. Glenn

utterance: Graham's got his gun again all right.
speaker: unspecified

utterance:
You were on post on Number Three last
evening, Mr. Jennings, and for full
an hour before tattoo, when Mr. Graham's new
rifle was exchanged for an old rusty one. The
new rifle was found in the weeds near the dump
hollow close to your post. Did no one cross your
post?
speaker: Mr. Glenn

utterance:
Not a soul that I saw, and unless it was found in the
south ditch of Fort Clinton, it must have been
hidden nearer Number Two's day post than
mine.
speaker: Jennings

utterance:
We have questioned Number Two. He denies all knowledge of it.
He says, what's more, that nobody could have
got away without his seeing him. It was Mr.
Douglas, of the Fourth Class, as you know, and
this was his third tour.
speaker: Mr. Glenn

utterance:
Oh, I can't pretend to say no one got across
my post. No one can be at all parts of that long
beat at the same time. It was cloudy, too, and
pitch dark. Anybody could have crossed up
there at the west end while I was down by your
tent. If the gun was found there, it is more than
likely some one did cross.
hard with him if I'd caught him.
speaker: Jennings

utterance:
Then you're sure you saw no one had no
conversation with anybody?
speaker: Mr. Glenn

utterance:
I saw no one cross. I held conversation with
half a dozen-class-mates and plebes both-when
I happened to be down by the tank. There were
Cresswell and Drake, and Curry early in the
evening; they were condoling with me about
being broke.' Then there were plebes coming
down there frequently; I had more or less chaff
with them, and Major-General Frazier among
them. I heard him spouting about his ex-
ploits. Where was the rifle found?
speaker: Jennings

utterance:
Oh, out near the east end of the old dump
hollow, hidden among the weeds and rubbish.
speaker: Cadet Captain Leonard

utterance:
But never mind that just now.
It was brought to my tent, and you are reported
to have said you thought it was the work of some
plebe. Why?
speaker: Cadet Captain Leonard

utterance:
Well, lots of 'em are jealous of Mr. Graham
for getting colors so easily for one thing. They
think the commandant shows him partiality.
They say it's because Graham's father is an army
officer. That's why I think they might have put
up the job among themselves.
speaker: Jennings

utterance:
Yes? And how did they know where the
old gun was hidden-the one that was taken from
him the night he was dumped into the ditch off
Number Three? You think plebes did that?
speaker: Cadet Captain Leonard

utterance:
He's got more reports on the delinquency
books than any one in the class.
speaker: Pops

utterance:
Yes, and more
of 'em off.
speaker: Connell

utterance:
None at all. I suppose I did
laugh-I couldn't help it.
speaker: George Montrose Graham

utterance:
Well, you bet I don't mean to swal-
low any two or three demerit if an explanation
will get it off.
speaker: Benjamin Franklin Frazier

utterance:
Mr. Graham, you have offered no
explanation for laughing in ranks at parade;
most of those reported have done so; why didn't
you?
speaker: The Colonel

utterance:
The report was
true, sir. I couldn't help it exactly, but—I had
no excuse.
speaker: George Montrose Graham

utterance:
Well, in a case like this, where something
comical really appeared, I do not care to see a
cadet punished, provided he comes forward and
explains the matter. Your tent-mate, for in-
stance, explains it very well, and says he couldn't
help smiling a little, so I took his report off as a
matter of course. It seems to me you have al-
lowed several reports to stand against you that
were removed in his case. I shall remove this
one. That is all, sir.
speaker: The Colonel

utterance:
Mr. Graham, your confinement in camp will
expire next week, and I understand Mr. Jennings
is saying that as soon as you are released you
will have to meet either Mr. Woods or himself.
I have seen Mr. Woods, and told him that you
have done all that is necessary; that he was
wrong in the first place. Now should Mr. Jen-
nings make any demands, I wish you to refuse,
and refer him to me.
speaker: Mr. Glenn

utterance:
Pops, do you
know anything about it? Jennings has just been put in arrest-conduct unbecoming a cadet and
a gentleman-and they say it's about your rifle.
speaker: Benjamin Franklin Frazier

utterance: Asking him to get me some cigarettes.
speaker: Benjamin Franklin Frazier

utterance:
You are wanted at once at the court-room;
so is that Major-General tent-mate of yours. Get
ready as quick as you can, Mr. Graham. Full
dress, with side arms.
speaker: unspecified

utterance: I do.
speaker: George Montrose Graham

utterance: What was the number of the new rifle?
speaker: judge-advocate

utterance:
I want that drummer Doyle at once. Why
is he not here?
speaker: judge-advocate

utterance: We can't find him, sir, anywhere.
speaker: orderly

utterance:
Well, go again, and tell the drum-major to
have him hunted up. He had no business to let
him away from barracks.
speaker: judge-advocate

utterance:
Detained as a witness before the court-mar
tial.
speaker: officer of the day

utterance:
Wait un-
til you hear the whole story.
speaker: Mr. Ross

utterance:
It
can't be told now, but will be when the excite
ment has died away and it is safe to tell it.
speaker: Mr. Ross

utterance:
I can't tell as yet. I've given my word to
Ross and Jennings. Don't go back on me, Graham, and
you'll never regret it.
speaker: Benjamin Franklin Frazier

utterance:
I was
going to room with Foster, but I'd far rather
live with you. Do you think we can fix it now?
Foster is willing to live with Clawson
speaker: Connell

utterance:
I've promised to live with Frazier, and though
I'd rather live with you than any man I know, I
won't go back on my promise.
speaker: George Montrose Graham

utterance:
They're all down on me now, Graham,
and if you turn from me I won't have a friend
left in the class. If you and I room together,
they'll know you don't believe me mean enough
to take your gun. Appearances are all against
me simply because I can't tell without involving
some poor fellows whom dismissal would ruin
for life just because they'd taken part in what
they meant to be only a joke.
speaker: Benjamin Franklin Frazier

utterance:
Look here, Frazier, does nobody keep prom
ises where you come from?
speaker: George Montrose Graham

utterance: Keep your eyes to the front, plebe.
speaker: red-sashed first sergeant

utterance: Take your post, sir.
speaker: Colonel Hazzard

utterance:
Why, I don't believe I've ever heard him
speak ten words. What makes them put such
galoots in command of sections when there's
others, like you, for instance, that know how to
handle 'em?
speaker: Benjamin Franklin Frazier

utterance:
It's all part and parcel of the system of teach
ing fellows like me, as you put it, that obedience
is the first thing we have to learn.
speaker: George Montrose Graham

utterance:
I am required to discuss the Problem of the
Lights.
speaker: cadet

utterance:
I am required to deduce a rule for
such and such a purpose.
speaker: cadet

utterance:
Very
well, sir, that'll do.
speaker: instructor

utterance: I am excused from reciting, sir.
speaker: cadet

utterance:
I want you to come and walk with me, old
man.
speaker: Connell

utterance:
You were going to your room
to 'bone,' and I know it. Pops, don't do that.
What time we have to spend in the open air
you need to take for no other purpose. You'll
go to your work with a clearer head.
speaker: Connell

utterance: "Doesn't Frazier help you?"
speaker: Connell

utterance: "Not much. He's generally busy reading, writing, or dozing, and he's impatient of my stupidity, I suppose. Everything seems so easy to him,"
speaker: Pops

utterance: Yes, I never heard such finished recitations. 'Old Scad' just sits there and nods approval, and seldom asks a question." ("Old Scad" was the irreverent title given to a gray-headed lieuten- ant of artillery by a previous class, and plebes rarely fail to adopt such nicknames.) "Benny's 'maxing' right along just now,"
speaker: Connell

utterance: "Do you think he'll be head of the class?"
speaker: Pops

utterance: "He might, because he's just as fluent in French; but I'll bet my hopes of graduation against the corporal chevrons you're bound to wear next June that if he's head in January he'll never get there again."
speaker: Connell

utterance: "Why, Con? What do you mean ?"
speaker: Pops

utterance: "Simply this: Frazier is a sort of fireworks fellow. He's going up with a flash and a roar, but he'll burn out by the time we get into ana- lytical. He isn't a stayer. Mr. Otis was tell- ing me last night that there were cases where fellows who stood head in the plebe January dropped out of sight by the end of the third year. As for Frazier, he'll get found on demer- it if he isn't careful. He's smoking cigarettes again. Don't let him light one in the room."
speaker: Connell

utterance: "Oh, he doesn't so long as I am there. Of course if I get reported as orderly for tobacco smoke in quarters he'll be man enough to take it off my shoulders."
speaker: Pops

utterance: "I don't want to wrong Frazier, but I'm in- clined to think that the less you build on his doing the manly thing at his own expense the safer you'll be."
speaker: Connell

utterance: "You knew what would happen. How could you be so reckless of other fellows' rights?"
speaker: George Montrose Graham

utterance: "Didn't I tell you!"
speaker: Benjamin Franklin Frazier

utterance: "All the same, there must be no more of it when I'm orderly."
speaker: Pops

utterance: "I'd like to know how you'll stop it. You won't be so mean as to' skin' a room-mate, and get 'cut' by the whole class for doing it, will you?"
speaker: Benjamin Franklin Frazier

utterance: "You must be sick! I was only one of the lot; 'tisn't as though I did it all alone."
speaker: Benjamin Franklin Frazier

utterance: "Nothing, sir,"
speaker: George Montrose Graham

utterance: "If it occurred in your absence, Mr. Graham, and you did not see the smokers, or if you put a stop to it the mo- ment you did-"
speaker: Colonel Hazzard

utterance: "See here, Pops, if you think I ought to go and tell the commandant I was smoking, I'll do it; but it isn't going to help you, that I can see. It's all the fault of these brutal regulations, making you responsible be- cause you were too much of a gentleman to come in and order that smoking stopped in your room right off. If my confessing my part in it would remove your punishment, I'd do it quick as a cat can jump-but it couldn't, so what's the use?"
speaker: Benjamin Franklin Frazier

utterance: "I don't mean to make any trouble about this case, but I give fair warning I will take no more demerit and punishment on other men's account."
speaker: Pops

utterance: "I haven't even looked at it yet."
speaker: Benjamin Franklin Frazier

utterance: "Well, then, you'd better be doing it,"
speaker: some one

utterance: "I can do anything else in the lesson, sir, but not that,"
speaker: Harris

utterance: "This ought not to occur in the first section,"
speaker: "Scad"

utterance: "That 'll do."
speaker: "Scad"

utterance: "Mr. Frazier, take that demonstration."
speaker: "Scad"

utterance: "That'll do, Mr. Ames; that 'll do, Mr. Fra- zier. Section's dismissed!"
speaker: "Scad"

utterance: "I'd rather be the foot of the class with your reputation, Pops, than head of the corps with Frazier's,"
speaker: Connell

utterance: "It's all the fault of such outrageous rules and spying offi- cers,"
speaker: Benjamin Franklin Frazier

utterance: "I'm sorry they didn't name you as one of them, corporal, but I suppose you fel- lows from the frontier don't go much on society."
speaker: Benjamin Franklin Frazier

utterance: "Graham, I want to say before I go that I am heartily sorry for my part in our quarrel of last summer, and that you behaved perfectly right. Won't you shake hands?"
speaker: Mr. Woods

utterance: "You will kick me down-stairs, will you? You try it if you want to get kicked out of the corps of cadets. I'm not to be abused by the likes of you."
speaker: a drum-boy orderly

utterance: You know better than to speak to a cadet in that way. Go back to the guard-house.
speaker: unnamed character

utterance: I don't speak that way to any other gentleman in the corps, but I can't stand that fellow, neither can any of us, and you couldn't either if you knew what we know.
speaker: unnamed character

utterance: I told you not to return here.
speaker: George Montrose Graham

utterance: He-he had to apologize for his words, or-get into trouble.
speaker: Benjamin Franklin Frazier

utterance: Where are you going with that truck now? You've got to take it over to camp in the morning.
speaker: Benjamin Franklin Frazier

utterance: I'm not going to camp- at least, not now. And, Frazier, I've not yet said one word to anybody but yourself about this. I've told you twice that our ways were so different that we did not get along as we should as tent or room mates, so if you want to take anybody else, do so. It'll be some time before I come into camp, and then I shall slip into any vacancy that there may be. To be perfectly. frank, I cannot afford the demerit it costs me to live with you, and -I don't like cigarette smoke.
speaker: George Montrose Graham

utterance: Any more than you do me, I suppose. Now that you've got your chevrons, and passed to the Third Class, you've no further use for the fellow that helped you to both.
speaker: Benjamin Franklin Frazier

utterance: I've no word to say against you, Frazier, and you know it. I am obliged to you for what help you gave me, but I don't think I owe either my chevrons or my gain in standing to you.
speaker: George Montrose Graham

utterance: Oh, you've had this thing all cut and dried for weeks. You're simply moving over into Connell's room as a preliminary to moving into camp with him, leaving me to find a tent-mate at the last moment.
speaker: Benjamin Franklin Frazier

utterance: I am not going to Connell's. I am not going to camp. I told you so.
speaker: George Montrose Graham

utterance: Where, then? Where are you going to? Surely”— and here a sudden light dawned on Benny
speaker: Benjamin Franklin Frazier

utterance: surely you've not been turned out - over plebes. You are? You? Well, may I be blessed! Listen to this, fellows.
speaker: Benjamin Franklin Frazier

utterance: Well, why not?
speaker: unnamed character

utterance: What is there that seems ridiculous to you in that, Frazier?
speaker: unnamed character

utterance: Upbraided Pops for going back on him about the tent, did he? Well, the moment it was known, five days ago, that I was to act as sergeant - major this summer, Frazier came to ask me to choose him for a tent-nate and battalion clerk. He can make out a prettier set of papers than any man in the class, but I'd rather do all the work myself, and any fellow can tell him so that likes to.
speaker: Benton

utterance: And what's more, sir, you were right about Mr. Graham. Both the colonel and I thought him slow and perhaps lacking in force, but he has done admirably.
speaker: Lieutenant Allen

utterance: Yes, sir, and I believe he will be just as efficient in the battalion.
speaker: Cadet Captain Rice

utterance: He holds right over us; -a we're not in it with him as a drill-master
speaker: Harry Winn

utterance: That is excellent work, Mr. Graham. You deserve great credit, sir.
speaker: Colonel Hazzard

utterance: Good-evening, Mr. Graham: I hope you are well, sir
speaker: Mr. Frazier senior

utterance: It's all Benny boy's doings. That young prodigy is a well-bred, sweet-mannered cad.
speaker: Connell

utterance: The finest soldier of the lot, sir, as any com- petent and unprejudiced officer will tell you
speaker: Mr. Frazier senior

utterance: What's old man Frazier hobnobbing with drum-boys for?
speaker: Lieutenant Allen

utterance: I wish I could find out.
speaker: Lieutenant Breeze

utterance: Fall out, Frazier. You know perfectly well you have no business in ranks in that shape. Fall out, and fix your belts.
speaker: Connell

utterance: You're taking advantage of your size, that's what you're doing, Mr. Connell; and you wouldn't dare to speak to me in that tone if you weren't altogether too big for me to tackle.
speaker: Benjamin Franklin Frazier

utterance: Class-mate or no class-mate, you cannot appear in ranks of this company in that shape, and I want no words about it.
speaker: Connell

utterance: I hear that Frazier declared I was taking advantage of my size. Did you hear it?
speaker: Connell

utterance: I don't mean to see any more trouble be- tween you and Benny if I can help it, Con. He's making an ass of himself, but there sha'n't be any row if I can prevent it.
speaker: George Montrose Graham

utterance: I am too heavy to take advantage of you in any way, but in the whole class or the whole corps I challenge you to find one man who will say I have imposed in the faintest degree upon you. If you can, I'll beg your pardon; if not, by Jupiter, you must beg mine!
speaker: Connell

utterance: Connell was perfectly right, and you were utterly wrong. You've been wrong all along ever since we came in camp. You've imposed on him in every way you dared, and simply forced him to 'skin' you, or else stand convicted of showing you partiality. That's my opinion, since you ask it; and if I were in Connell's place you'd eat your words or fight-one of the two.
speaker: Brooks

utterance: My parents are here, as you very probably considered when you made your remarks, Mr. Brooks. I do not wish to fight while they're here. They go on Satur- day, and then we can settle this.
speaker: Benjamin Franklin Frazier

utterance: Any time you please, only don't wait too long.
speaker: Brooks

utterance: You have given your relations to understand that it was Graham who reported your language to me. It was Graham who refused to do it.
speaker: Connell

utterance: Why not?
speaker: Benjamin Franklin Frazier

utterance: For two reasons. First, because I agree with Brooks; and second, because you have no right whatever to ask me to second you.
speaker: George Montrose Graham

utterance: Coyote may be no mathematician, but he can outride any man in this class, by jinks! and give points to many a fel- low in the others.
speaker: Harry Winn

utterance: Stick to it, Geordie boy, we're proud of you. I have bet Lane you will be one of the four first sergeants in June and up among the twenties in class rank.
speaker: Ralph McCrea

utterance: Well, I don't want to give up until certain I can't do it myself, and it takes time.
speaker: George Montrose Graham

utterance: The firm of 'Badger & Coyote' is dissolved.
speaker: Harry Winn

utterance: and I'd rather have you than any man I know.
speaker: Bend

utterance: First sergeants and furlough-men, Pops, who'd 'a' thought it two years ago? Certainly not Frazier.
speaker: Connell

utterance: But it's proud I am to salute ye, sir, and then don't the regulations say a cadet ranks any sergeant in the army? Sure you and Mr. Connell are my supariors in law if ye are my juniors in years and chiverones.
speaker: Sergeant Feeny

utterance: Pops, you are going back to what I hold to be the hardest of the four years, and going withal to duties which, more than any others in the cadet battalion, call for all the grit there is in a man. A young fellow who does his whole duty as first sergeant must make enemies among the careless, the slouchy, and the stubborn in his company. I hold that no position in the battalion is so calculated to develop all that is soldierly and manly in a cadet as that of first sergeant. There are always upper class men who expect to be treated with consideration, even when they set bad examples; then there are year-lings always trying to be 'reekless' just to excite the envy of the plebes. You'll find it the toughest place you ever had to fill; but go at it with the sole idea of being square and soldierly, and in spite of all they may say or do you'll win the enduring respect of the very men who may buck against you and abuse you in every way. As for popularity, throw all idea of it to the winds; it isn't worth having. Teach them to respect you, and their esteem and affection will certainly follow.
speaker: Ralph McCrea

utterance: Sergeant-major may sound bigger, but in point of importance in the corps of cadets it simply isn't in it alongside that of first sergeant. My father can't break himself of the old fashions of the war days. He was 'or-derly' sergeant, as they called it in '61, and he takes more stock in my being 'orderly' than my being in the 5's.
speaker: Connell

utterance: We may need that more than we think, Pops. That fellow Jennings is stirring up trouble, unless I am mistaken.
speaker: Connell

utterance: There's no reason that I can see, why First Class men shouldn't be just as soldierly in ranks as other cadets, and every reason why they should.
speaker: Connell

utterance: Jennings is at the bottom of it all. He wants them, however, to start the move over in D Company, because he can't initiate anything of the kind under Bend. You understand.
speaker: Connell

utterance: Well, to my thinking, and according to the way I was brought up, such specimens should be court-martialled and dismissed the service. Men who have no higher idea of duty than that are not fit to be officers in the army.
speaker: George Montrose Graham

utterance: We-el, they are boys only a little older than plebes, so far as knowledge of the world is concerned. The more I look at it the more I see just how comically juvenile we are in a way. When we were plebes, dozens of our class were never going to speak to those fellows of the yearlings, and never, never going to devil plebes. Within a year most of us were hobnobbing with the class above and lording it over the class below. As yearlings, lots of our fellows hated the first sergeants, who made us stand round, and we weren't going to have anything to do with them. Now we who are sergeants not only mean to make the year-lings toe the mark, but the First Class men as well, and they are going to force a fight on us for doing the very thing that in three or four years from now any one of their number who happens to be on duty here as an instructor will report a first sergeant for not doing. The whole corps says that when 'it' comes back here as an officer it won't forget it ever was a cadet, as every officer seems to do the moment he gets here, and you can bet your sash and chevrons it will do just exactly as the officers seem to do to-day. Now these fellows have an overweening idea of their importance because they are so soon to be graduates. That seems something very big from our point of view, and yet about the first thing a second lieutenant has to learn when he gets to his regiment is that he doesn't amount to a hill of beans. He's nothing but a plebe all over again. There's Jim Forester; when he was cadet officer of the day and we were plebes, didn't we think him just a little tin god on wheels? Recollect what a bully voice he had, and how he used to swing old D Company? But what did he amount to at Fort Reynolds last summer? Nothing but a low-down second lieutenant going on as officer of the guard, drilling squads, and do you remember how the colonel jumped him that morning for some error in the guard list? Why, Geordie, you and I were of much more account at the fort than he was. And now here are these fellows kicking against the pricks. They don't want to be soldierly, because it's too plebelike in view of their coming shoulder-straps. We-el, they've just got to, that's all there is about it. Where are the gloves?
speaker: Connell

utterance: Curry, fall out and button that coat.
speaker: George Montrose Graham

utterance: Curry, fall out at once and button that coat.
speaker: George Montrose Graham

utterance: My coat is buttoned.
speaker: Mr. Curry

utterance: It was unbuttoned throughout when you fell in ranks, and you know it. You also heard my order to fall out, and disobeyed it.
speaker: George Montrose Graham

utterance: Mr. Graham, you have taken advantage of Mr. Curry's size, and in his name and in that of the First Class I am here to demand satisfaction.
speaker: Jennings

utterance: Go for Connell.
speaker: George Montrose Graham

utterance: In time of peace prepare for war, however. There's no surer way of keeping the peace than being ready for anything that may turn up.
speaker: Connell

utterance: We'll have to be doing this sort of thing next year, Pops, so we may as well go and pick up pointers.
speaker: Connell

utterance: Oh, Mr. Graham, the officer of the day is inspecting for men in confinement, and Mr. Jennings and Mr. Frazier are both out.
speaker: plebes

utterance: Frazier! Jennings! Quick!
speaker: George Montrose Graham

utterance: Back to your room, Frazier! Inspection!
speaker: George Montrose Graham

utterance: Hello, Coyote! Tired of the light fantastic? or didn't you hop to-night?
speaker: officer of the day

utterance: Had to come back to bone.
speaker: George Montrose Graham

utterance: Graham, you did me a great service-me and Jennings-to-night. I-I know-we haven't got along as well as we should, and I suppose I am partially to blame; but I don't want you to think I can't appreciate the risk you ran to save us, though either of us, of course, would have done as much for you- any time. You know that, I hope. We had some business out there, and d-did you see the others so as to know them?
speaker: Benjamin Franklin Frazier

utterance: I knew the drummer well enough.
speaker: George Montrose Graham

utterance: Well, the other one's a cit. who's doing something for us. Say, one good turn deserves another. Don't tell anybody. about where you saw us, or who were with us, will you? I wouldn't like it to get out on Jennings's account. He's got to work like a dog to graduate, as it is.
speaker: Benjamin Franklin Frazier

utterance: Remember what I asked you
speaker: Benjamin Franklin Frazier

utterance: How are the mighty fallen! They say he's going 'way down in both Phil. and Chem. in January. He has no French to help him now. Benton thinks he'll tumble into the low thirties. What did he want of you?
speaker: Ames

utterance: Nothing to speak of. He-e-said he came to thank me for giving that warning.
speaker: George Montrose Graham

utterance: Oh, thanks be blowed! He never came to thank you, Pops. That was only a pretext. He came to ask you to do or not to do something on his account, and I know it.
speaker: Ames

utterance: What in the world is the tie that binds those two?
speaker: neighbors

utterance: You can hear them snapping and snarling at one another at any hour of the day or night.
speaker: neighbors

utterance: If Frazier hates him so, why on earth doesn't he 'shake' him?
speaker: neighbors

utterance: They're getting enough demerit between them to swamp half a dozen men.
speaker: neighbors

utterance: I-I-thought it was Jennings. What's wanted?
speaker: Benjamin Franklin Frazier

utterance: I came to tell you Ewen would go on sick report, and you'd have to march on guard in his place.
speaker: George Montrose Graham

utterance: But, Frazier, I hate to see you looking so miserable. If you're in trouble, can't you let us help you out? There are plenty of fellows left to be your friends. It doesn't become me to say anything against your room-mate, but lots of us think you would do well to cut loose from him.
speaker: George Montrose Graham

utterance: Cut loose-from him?
speaker: Benjamin Franklin Frazier

utterance: Oh, if I only-
speaker: Benjamin Franklin Frazier

utterance: To what circumstance do we owe the honor of this visit?
speaker: Jennings

utterance: Frazier, any time you feel like dropping in on Ames and me, come, and be sure of a welcome.
speaker: George Montrose Graham

utterance: You brute! How dare you grapple a little fellow like that?
speaker: George Montrose Graham

utterance: Back, Jennings! Down with him!
speaker: Mr. Bend

utterance: Stand where you are, sir. What does all this mean? What has he done to you, Frazier ?
speaker: Mr. Bend

utterance: Give him some water and lay him down on the bed. Don't crowd around him. He needs air. Get out, all of you!
speaker: Mr. Bend

utterance: Back to your quarters!
speaker: Mr. Bend

utterance: He insulted and defied me. He insulted my people, my kith and kin. I dare him to deny it, or to tell what led to this. Take your hands off of me, you fellows; I'm no criminal. If you're laying for a thief, there's your game yonder.
speaker: Jennings

utterance: Shut up, Jennings; that's cowardly.
speaker: Mr. Bend

utterance: Cowardly, is it? You'll rue those words, my fine fellow. I thrashed you well once, and I've just been praying for another chance, and now I've got it. Cowardly, is it? By Heaven, you'll smart for that!
speaker: Jennings

utterance: Go for Dr. Brett.
speaker: Lieutenant Allen

utterance: There seems to be no reasonable doubt that you are your room-mate's assailant, Mr. Jennings. You are placed in close arrest, sir.
speaker: Lieutenant Allen

utterance: I wonder I am not jealous, but I thank God my poor boy has such a friend left to him, after all his trouble-all the misery into which that-that awful person has led and held him.
speaker: Mrs. Frazier

utterance: Tar-and-feather him!
speaker: cadets

utterance: Kick him out!
speaker: cadets

utterance: Turn him loose and let him run the gantlet!
speaker: cadets

utterance: All present, sir!
speaker: Wright

utterance: If Wright's made first captain, he'll go to sleep some day, and the corps will march right away from him.
speaker: cadet captain

utterance: Dismiss the company!
speaker: Mr. Bend

utterance: Go it, Coyote, go it! By jimminy! there isn't a man in the class that would begrudge you the first place if you can get it.
speaker: Connell

utterance: and no one, would better grace or deserve it.
speaker: Connell and George Montrose Graham

utterance: "Pops, dear old boy, nobody's gladder than I am!"
speaker: Benjamin Franklin Frazier

utterance: "thought it should go to Con."
speaker: George Montrose Graham

utterance: "all right,"
speaker: Wright

utterance:
"Why, Pops, honest Injun, I'd hate to leave
old D, now that I've got to know them all so well;
and I tell you candidly if I expect to land in the
Engineers next June I want nothing to interfere
with my studies meantime, and first captaincy
is a powerful tax on a man's time and thought.
But even outside of that, old man, I believe you
deserve it more and will honor it more than any
fellow in the class."
speaker: Connell

utterance:
"I have head
enough left to see that I have got to work out
my own salvation, Geordie, and you can't make
them like me."
speaker: Benjamin Franklin Frazier

utterance:
"Even in Rand's day you
never saw better order or discipline in the hall
or in the ranks, and the best of
it is, the battalion wants to do as he wishes."
speaker: Connell

utterance:
"I have been calling at Dr. Brett's this
afternoon, and they expect their relief next week.
They've been here four years, you know."
speaker: Benjamin Franklin Frazier

utterance:
"Your mother promised to 'sit out' three
dances with me, Benny. Tell her I shall come
early to claim them."
speaker: George Montrose Graham

utterance:
"Does Graham make as fine a first captain as
we thought he would?"
speaker: returned furlough sergeant

utterance:
"Tip-top! I don't think there ever was a bet-
ter one.
But from the instant he draws sword
in command of that battalion he doesn't know
anybody."
speaker: one of the seniors

utterance: "Fall out, sir; Mr. Connell takes command."
speaker: Colonel Hazzard

utterance:
"If that wasn't a low-down trick to play on
Coyote, I never heard of one. Old Scad never evolved
a harder test. Think of parading a fellow's
mother at the saluting point when he hadn't seen
her for a whole year, just to prove that he's such
a soldier he couldn't forget himself even then."
speaker: Harry Winn

utterance:
"She makes me think of Ailie in 'Rab and his
Friends,'"
speaker: Lieutenant Allen

utterance:
"Coyote is spooney over his
mother and nobody else."
speaker: the class

utterance: "Graham!"
speaker: the secretary

utterance:
"face the music' and to meet the eye of every member of his
year's command and such a whirlwind of cheers
as he had never heard before."
speaker: George Montrose Graham

utterance:
"Keep it for
me while I go to change my dress. You are the last to say good-bye to the gray.
Come close to the first division, so that you may
be the first to greet me in cits. And, mother,
don't you dare-don't you dare call me lieu-
tenant."
speaker: George Montrose Graham
